description.narrative:
Cambodia Development Resource Institute (CDRI) insände i april 2016 projektförslaget "CDRI-Sida Partnership" för perioden juli 2016 till juni 2021. Förslaget bygger vidare på det stöd som Sida har gett till CDRI sedan början av 1990-talet. Ansökan utgår från CDRI:s strategiska plan för 2016-2021 och med stöd av de aktiviteter som förslaget föreslår, så väntas målen enligt strategiska planen uppnås. Stödet avses - likt föregående stöd - att ges i form av ett så kallat "kärnstöd" (verksamhetsstöd) till forskningsinstitutionen med fokus på fem huvudteman: jordbruk, ekonomi, utbildning, miljö och förvaltning. CDRI:s evidensbaserade forskningsresultat håller hög kvalitet och kan därmed bidra med evidensbaserade underlag för policybeslut, reformer och påverkansarbete på både central och lokal nivå.
Den totala budgeten för Sidas planerade stöd motsvarar SEK 25,5 miljoner varav SEK 500 000 avsätts och används av Sida för att genomföra en halvtidsöversyn under 2019.

participating-org.narrative: University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution, Cambodia Development Resource Institute 2016-2021

description.narrative: During 2018 CDRI had in general a successful year in line with strategy and plans. Demand for CDRI’s research publications at high-profile events is increasing, as well as from universities, government agencies, research institutions and NGOs among others, and the volume of downloads from CDRI’s website are a demonstration of the capabilities of CDRI’s inhouse publishing and the quality of the publications. The printed publications however anchor CDRI’s reputation as a leading research institute and raise Cambodian researchers’ profiles internationally and in country. Some of the research highlights from 2018 were: On-farm Food Safety in Horticulture in Cambodia: The Case of Vegetable Farming promoted both the safety and sustainability of domestic production through the use of good agricultural practices and pesticides management. By mapping production processes from farmer to exporter, the research team was able to identify challenges and solutions for improving access to market information for poor and small-scale farmers. Accountability Concepts and Approaches at Cambodian Universities and Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation in Higher Education were instrumental for the development of Cambodia’s Higher Education Vision 2030 and the drafting of the new Science, Technology and Innovation Policy of the Government. Climate Change Adaptation used a participatory action research approach to carry out vulnerability risk assessments and evaluate local disaster risk reduction initiatives in provinces that are most vulnerable to climate change. The complexity and interconnectivity of risks in agriculture demanded a highly integrated approach involving stakeholders from local level to central government. Training targeted at local female leaders facilitated integration of change adaptation planning into commune development plans. New Generation, Subnational Governance and Political Pluralism focused on demographic change and youth rural-urban migration. The report, the first of its kind in Cambodia, was based on a nationally representative survey on political participation of youth, analysing the changing patterns of young people’s political engagement in general and especially in the decentralisation reform since the 2013 general election. The youth survey results suggest that demographic change in Cambodia has significant social and political impact. Young Cambodians differ in important ways from their parents’ generation specifically in education, employment, mobility and access to technology and information. Youth are more assertive and given more decision-making authority within the household by older generations. They are also more optimistic about their future and that of the country. They expect progress in material and non-material wellbeing and demand greater opportunities to influence decisions and policies that affect them personally, their families and communities During the year CDRI expanded its network to include more regional partners and research programs. This included international research collaborations such as the Contribution of Vocational Skills Development to Inclusive Industrial Growth and Transformation: An Analysis of Critical Factors – Skills for Industry. This project is led by Zürich University of Teacher Education and involves a consortium of research teams from Bangladesh, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Ethiopia and South Africa. CDRI was also awarded two research grants totalling USD1 million over two years (2018–19) under the Mekong-Lancang Cooperation Special Fund. CDRI coordinates the Greater Mekong Subregion Research Network (GMS-Net), a network of research institutes in the Mekong region. GMS-Net’s latest regional study involved eight country research teams and focused on Improving Job Prospects for Youth, Low-Skilled and Women Workers in the Mekong Region.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
